IconKeyExplanation: Symbolizing the key component of water
Helium is often filled in balloons
Lithium is used in rechargeable batteries
Beryllium is sourced from minerals in mountains
Boron is used in borosilicate glasses
column6: which can be found in some reading glasses

IconKeyExplanation: Carbon forms diamonds under pressure
Nitrogen causes cyclonic activity in the atmosphere
Oxygen is essential for plant photosynthesis
Fluoride is used in toothpaste for healthy teeth
Neon lights are used in many light bulbs
Represents sodium's presence in table salt (sodium chloride)
Magnesium is vital for photosynthesis
Aluminum is used in aircraft construction
Silicon is abundant in sand
Phosphorescent materials glow
Sulfur has that "rotten egg" smell
Chlorine is commonly used to treat swimming pool water
Argon is used in neon lights
Potassium is abundant in bananas
Calcium is essential for strong bones
Scandium is used in some aerospace applications
column6: hence a link to the galaxy

IconKeyExplanation: Titanium is known for its strength and is used in various alloys
Vanadium is used to make strong steel for pots and pans
Chrome has a shiny and sparkling appearance
Manganese is used in alloy steels which can be magnetic
Iron is a primary component in tools like hammers
Cobalt is used in making strong permanent magnets
Nickel is used in certain types of batteries
Copper is commonly used in coins
Zinc is used in protective galvanizing
Gallium melts near room temperature
Germanium is used in transistors in some electronic devices like speakers
Arsenic
column7: is historically associated with the venom of some creatures like scorpions

IconKeyExplanation: Selenium is used in some photocells found in cameras
Bromine is used in some types of lamps
Krypton is used in certain high-performance light bulbs
Rubidium is used in atomic clocks
Strontium is used in firework to produce a red flame
Yttrium is used in some mobile phone screens
Zirconium is often found in some decorative crystals used in jewelry
Niobium is used in alloys that have superconducting properties
column6: represented by the range of colors in a rainbow.

IconKeyExplanation: Molybdenum is used in steel alloys to enhance strength
column6: commonly found in tools like wrenches.

IconKeyExplanation: Technetium is the first element with no stable isotopes
column6: represented by the temporary nature of an hourglass.

IconKeyExplanation: Ruthenium is used in electrical contacts and is hard like diamonds.
Rhodium is used in catalytic converters for cars.
Palladium is used in dental fillings and crowns.
Silver is used in utensils like spoons.
Cadmium is used in rechargeable nickel-cadmium batteries.
Indium is used in making touchscreens and LCDs of televisions.
Tin is used in making cans for food storage.
Antimony is used in semiconductors and some electrical plugs.
Tellurium is used in certain types of CDs and DVDs.
Iodine is essential for the human diet and is added to table salt.
Xenon is used in certain types of high-intensity lamps.
Cesium is used in atomic clocks.
Barium is used in X-ray diagnostic work to highlight certain areas of the body.
Lanthanum is used in the glass used in camera and telescope lenses.
Cerium is used in making strong magnets.
Praseodymium is used in coloring glasses and enamels
Neodymium is used in headphones and loudspeaker magnets.

Promethium is used in luminous paint
column8: and instruments to be read in the dark.

IconKeyExplanation: Samarium is used in cancer treatment and in certain nuclear reactors.
Europium is used in fluorescent light bulbs.
Gadolinium is used as a contrast agent in MRI scanning.
Terbium is used in color television tubes and fluorescent lamps.
Dysprosium is crucial for the production of hard drive disks and high-performance magnets.
Holmium is used in a variety of electronic equipment and has magnetic properties.
Erbium is used in the telecommunications industry
Thulium is used in portable X-ray machines and is also found in some dental equipment.
Ytterbium can be used to help improve the grain refinement
column7: and other mechanical properties of stainless steel.

IconKeyExplanation: Lutetium is used in various research applications and in petroleum refining.
Hafnium is used in equipment that operates at high temperatures.
Tantalum is used in the manufacturing of electronic components
column6: particularly in capacitors for mobile phones.

IconKeyExplanation: Tungsten (often referred to as "Wolfram") is used in light bulb filaments.
Rhenium is used in jet engines.
Osmium
column7: is used in fountain pen tips and electrical contacts
column8: and historically in phonograph needles. It forms strong alloys with platinum used in jewelry.

IconKeyExplanation: Iridium is used in fountain pen tips.
Platinum is often used in jewelry due to its resistance to corrosion.
Gold (Au) is used in jewelry
Mercury is famously known for its use in thermometers.
Thallium was historically used in rat poisons and insecticides
column6: and is now used in some types of batteries.

IconKeyExplanation: Lead is used in batteries
column7: and was historically used in paints and pipes.

IconKeyExplanation: Bismuth compounds are used in cosmetics
Polonium is a highly radioactive element.
Astatine is a rare
column6: radioactive element with very few uses
column7: represented by the alembic (a symbol for alchemy and research).

IconKeyExplanation: Radon is a radioactive gas known for its presence in homes and its health risks.
Francium is a highly reactive metal.
Radium was historically used in luminous paint for watch dials.
Actinium glows faintly in the dark due to its radioactivity and was named after the Greek word for 'ray'.
Thorium is a naturally occurring radioactive metal that has been considered as an alternative nuclear fuel.
Protactinium was first identified in 1913 by Kasimir Fajans and Oswald Helmuth GÃ¶hring and was named after the Greek word 'proto'
column7: to highlight its position in the periodic table.

IconKeyExplanation: Uranium is a heavy metal used as fuel in nuclear power plants.
Neptunium was the first synthetic transuranium element of the actinide series
Plutonium is used in nuclear weapons and reactors.
Americium is used in smoke detectors and some types of batteries.
Curium is used in research and has been used in space missions as a heat source.
Berkelium was named after the city of Berkeley
Californium is used in neutron moisture gauges and as a neutron source.
Einsteinium was named after the physicist Albert Einstein.
Fermium was named after physicist Enrico Fermi
column6: and the radio represents Fermi's contributions to the development of the first nuclear reactor.

IconKeyExplanation: Mendelevium is named after the "father" of the periodic table
column7: and the stethoscope represents the scientific contribution.

IconKeyExplanation: Nobelium is named after Alfred Nobel
column6: who is known for the Nobel Prizes (and dynamite). The "No Entry" sign is a play on the element's symbol "No".

IconKeyExplanation: Lawrencium is named after the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory; the flashlight represents exploration and discovery.
Rutherfordium is named after Ernest Rutherford
column6: known for his model of the atom; the tornado represents the dynamic nature of atoms.

IconKeyExplanation: Dubnium's naming was controversial between Russian and American scientists. The guitar represents a rock-n-roll (or 'rocky') journey.
Seaborgium is named after Glenn T. Seaborg
column6: a great scientist and communicator; hence

IconKeyExplanation: Bohrium is named after Niels Bohr; the bridge symbolizes the Bohr model's impact in bridging classical and quantum physics.
Hassium is named after the German state of Hesse. The landscape icon represents regions or states.
Meitnerium is named after Lise Meitner. The mountain represents the peaks of scientific discovery.
Darmstadtium is named after the city of Darmstadt. The theatre masks represent the city's cultural significance.
Roentgenium is named after Wilhelm Conrad RÃ¶ntgen
column6: the discoverer of X-rays. The rainbow represents the spectrum of X-rays.

IconKeyExplanation: Copernicium is named after Nicolaus Copernicus. The paintbrush symbolizes the Renaissance period and the art of discovery.
Nihonium is named after Japan (Nihon in Japanese). Sushi is a well-known Japanese dish.
Flerovium is named after the Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions. The plug symbolizes the element's connection to nuclear science.
Moscovium is named after the Moscow region. The galaxy represents the vastness of scientific exploration.
Livermorium is named after Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. The volcano represents explosive discoveries.
Tennessine is named after the state of Tennessee
column6: known for its scientific contributions. The cyclone represents dynamic and transformative research.

IconKeyExplanation: Oganesson is named after Yuri Oganessian. Being a noble gas
column6: the balloon symbolizes elements that are typically unreactive and light.
